On Fri, 15 Jul 2005, Ashot_Petrosian wrote:

> 	I have implemented a Python version of NEAT myself which is
> feature-complete and has been successfully tested on XOR and double
> pole balancing, and which I'm using now to evolve controllers for some
> simple soccer playing bots.  I should say that my version is not a
> carbon copy of the original in implementation and is in fact different
> in a few areas by quite a bit (although I think functionally mostly
> equivalent).  The three biggest differences that I can think of are
> that speciation is done continuously without distinct species
> (individuals get fitness modifications depending on how new and how
> rare their innovations are, and probablistically mated based on
> similarity), there is no genotype - crossover and mutation is just
> done directly, and links don't have their own innovation ids (instead
> its a tuple of the innovation ids that they connect).   I can describe
> these in more detail, but I don't think they are very interesting.
> Suffice it to say that I can't guarantee that this will work
> identically to original NEAT on every problem, although it has done
> well thus far.

This is very neat work (if you'll pardon the pun). Can you elaborate more 
on your speciation/fitness modification methods?

> 	Also, I have implemented a module to save and retrieve networks and
> evolutionary runs to and from a mySQL database, a module to visualize
> arbitrary parameters from the database, a 3d network visualizer, and a
> soccer domain with a monitor.  I ported the network evaluation code to
> Pyrex (C) to speed up the simulations some as well.  If Tom or anyone
> else is interested in any this the code it is relatively simple (the
> part that implements NEAT is ~500 lines), it will be here soon (once
> I'm finished cleaning it):
>
> 	http://www.freshraisins.com/neat
>
> 	(at the moment you can see a screenshot and some videos of evolved
> behaviour)

This is a very nice network visualization, is the code python as well? And 
a bigger question, is it portable to linux? :)

> 	Joe (or anyone really) - I haven't had a chance to look at your code
> yet, but I am curious to know how you kept the GA and the network
> seperate and still had innovation numbers?  I found that this was the
> most difficult thing to deal with and essentially made any sort of
> strict meaningful OO seperation difficult to impossible.

My most recent implementation uses a function like:

network = genotype_to_phenotype( genome )

I think Ken's implementation does this as well. MNEAT implemented networks 
as a class that took in a genome in the constructor. I'm not sure if this 
meets the criterion of "strict meaningful OO separation" but it seems 
clean enough to me.

> 	Also, when I was first looking over Ken's code as a reference I
> massaged his comments into Natural Docs format, in case someone finds
> this useful it is here:
>
> 	http://www.freshraisins.com/neatdoc

This is very nice as well, though honestly I have very fond memories of 
printing out the original NEAT C source code and marking it up with a 
highlighter. :P You should petition Ken to get a link to this on his NEAT 
site.

Joe

--
